column2: The official name, usually as registered with the Charity Commission.
column3: There's not a fixed taxonomy, but try to anticipate the things that people might search for if they are looking for charities like this
column7: The registration number with the Charity Commission of England & Wales
column8: Does it accept donations from the public? E.g. certain trusts for specific donors wouldn't do this. Any entry in here *must* start with Yes or No
column9: Add your name if you've contributed to this data collection!
column10: This is for when a charity has multiple projects and we've split the analysis up. The Overall category is for the aggregate -- every charity should have a row called "overall"
column11: the official timeperiod covered by the report in question.
column13: I.e. is gift aid available? (so for example if it's a multinational group with a U.K. entity, then the answer would be "Yes")
column14: Link to the charity's page on the charity commission website. Only relevant for those which are registered with the charity commission - or if it's a registered charity in Scotland show the relevant page on the OSCR website, and similarly for the charity commission of Northern Ireland
column15: Source 1: URL - this is typically going to be the annual report from the charity commission website
column17: Comments/more detail - e.g. page reference for the number of beneficiaries or anything that was particularly hard to find
column18: number, usually listed in the prose
column19: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, indicate the singular in brackets; try to keep this to about 2 words, and certainly no more than 5 words long
column20: Expand on the short version in a way that clarifies the short version. This could involve explaining more about what the short version means, and also indicating things like whether it's an average over lots of different projects or just refers to one project
column21: Sometimes the accounts will refer to "indirect beneficiaries" - include those here. Alternatively include the knock-on impacts or second order impacts in this column
column22: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side
column24: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side
column26: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side
column28: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side
column30: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side
column31: This is the overall total costs
column32: Income from beneficiaries - should include income that's generated by activity that helps beneficiaries (typically selling things to beneficiaries). Accounting guidelines encourage charities to show grant funds as "income from charitable activities", so the figures labelled as "income from charitable activities" in accounts are often not what we need. Reviewing the figures by looking at the notes to the accounts often provides the level of detail needed to judge this correctly. Looking for reason to believe that if this funding disappeared, the charity has the option to simply not do the activity any more.
column33: How much of the "cost" quoted was spent on revenue generating trading/business of the charity. Doesn't include trading where the counterparty of the trade is a beneficiary of the charity (i.e. where the trading *is* part of the charitable work) - this would be income from charitable activities instead)
column34: We deduct the money spent on trading and fundraising to find the money spent on the beneficiaries. The reason for this is just simplicity: if money spent fundraising and on trading just raised itself over again, it'd be the same as if it'd just sat in the bank that year, appearing neither on the cost nor income ledgers.
column41: If the cost per beneficiary calclauted in the spreadsheet is an upper bound for the true cost say yes here otherwise leave blank
column42: Explain here if any changes to the calc of cost per ben/output/outcome. Leave blank if no adhoc adjustment
column44: For UK charities only - look only at the UK-specific entity only. If there is no UK entity, enter zero, because there's zero income coming to a uk entity
column45: For UK charities only - look only at the UK-specific entity only. If there is no UK entity, enter zero, because there's zero income coming to a uk entity
column46: Amount of reserves is usually stated in the "wordy bit" (c first half of the accounts)
column48: Source (ie which page number in the accounts) ; what is the target level of the reserves, and how does this compare. If you notice any risks such as underisked pension schemes or FX risk, then mention those here too
column50: Where a charity has several projects, we may have to choose one as the representative project. For really big mega-charities, it may be necessary to have the "representative" row being an aggregate or "average" of all the projects
column51: Is there enough data to include in the SoGive app? A judgement
column52: An indicator of the confidence we have in the data, especially the cost per impact
column56: This is the qualitative bit about what your donation achieves. Stories about beneficiaries (either as a link, or copied and pasted - if copied and pasted also include a source). Sometimes this is available in the annual report and accounts, but may need to look on the charity's website
column59: A link to an image of a beneficiary. Sometimes this is available in the annual report and accounts, but may need to look on the charity's website
column60: A link to an image of a beneficiary. Sometimes this is available in the annual report and accounts, but may need to look on the charity's website
column61: Note - we might not need this; this will probably be deleted
column63: notes about if and when any emails were sent to the charity
column64: optional: Links to any external assessments
column65: NO LONGER REQUIRED. May be labelled as something like "costs of generating voluntary income"

column17: Can also look at http://rnli.org/aboutus/aboutthernli/Pages/Running-costs.aspx. lives saved stated on p3 of accounts
column43: 2015 lifeboat rescues + beach assistance + flooding rescues. Income from charitable activities given as £3.5m in the accounts - I've assumed that it's grants and therefore not income from charitable activities from the perspective of this database
column49: You helped rescue XXXX people from difficulty at sea, on beaches, or during flood conditions.
column54: RNLI works to save lives at sea around the coasts of Britain and Ireland through its work with lifeguards, lifeboats, and flood rescue.

column20: Lifeboats may be launched for anything from helping a boat with a fishing net caught in its propeller to a major life-threatening incident
column53: Minor cost allocation assumptions (Have assumed that the costs for the lifeboat work doesn't need any allocation for flood rescue work).
column54: RNLI works to save lives at sea around the coasts of Britain and Ireland through its work with lifeguards, lifeboats, and flood rescue.
column56: On a cold February night, RNLI volunteers from Scarborough launched their lifeboat into dark and treacherous conditions. Led by Helm Rudi Barman, they braved breaking 2m waves and whipping force 7 winds to reach Andrew McGeown. They brought him to shore and did everything they could to revive him. Tragically, Andrew was beyond help. Rudi received the RNLI’s Bronze Medal for Gallantry for his leadership, boathandling skills and bravery. ‘I don’t think anything can ever prepare you for a rescue like that,’ he says. ‘It was the most difficult rescue I’ve been on. But it’s something we train for day in, day out. To be recognised with an award like this is a great honour, but it’s not just me. There are many different wheels that work in this station down to the people who have trained me and the crew over the years.’
